title: Stephen Salerno
text:
I am a postdoctoral fellow in Biostatistics at the Fred Hutchinson Cancer Center, working with Jeff Leek. I received my PhD and MS in Biostatistics from the University of Michigan under the supervision of Yi Li, and a BS in Biometry and Statistics from Cornell University.
My research focuses on:

Statistical methods for drawing inference on algorithmically derived variables (post-prediction inference)

Deep learning for high-dimensional data

Survival analysis and causal questions in oncology and chronic disease

I also work on clinical quality measures, public reporting, and health policy, especially in kidney disease and lung cancer, and I am committed to building user-friendly software and contributing to data-for-good initiatives.

title: Stephen Salerno
text:
Research Overview
I currently focus on three main areas:

Inference with Predicted Data Developing methods like PPI, PPI++, PSPA, and related frameworks to enable valid downstream inference when key variables are imputed or predicted by complex models (e.g., deep neural networks, random forests).
Deep Learning and High-Dimensional Modeling Building and deploying deep learning models — often in R via torch and transformer architectures — for imaging and other high-dimensional biomedical data, with an emphasis on interpretability and integration with classical statistical models.
Survey Methods, Quality Measures, and Health Policy Methods for stratified and cluster sampling, bias correction, and variance estimation, with applications to clinical quality measure development, public reporting, and health policy in oncology and nephrology.

I aim to bridge modern machine learning with rigorous statistical inference, and to release open-source software so others can use these tools in applied research.

title: scorcher
text:
scorcher provides a composable, Keras Functional-style interface for building deep learning models in R using torch, with special attention to workflows needed for inference with predicted data.
Highlights:

Functional API for multi-input, multi-output architectures
Helpers for Hugging Face models and multimodal pipelines
Designed to play nicely with ipd and related inference tooling



GitHub: https://github.com/jtleek/scorcher
Documentation: in development

title: ipd
text:
ipd is an R package implementing a unifying framework for inference with predicted data, including methods such as PPI, RePPI, and prediction-powered inference variants.
Key features:

Unified interface that mirrors glm()
Support for multiple IPD estimators via a single high-level API
Tools for diagnostics, simulation, and workflow integration



GitHub: https://github.com/ipd-tools/ipd
Documentation: coming soon
DOI / paper: https://doi.org/10.1234/ipd-package

text:
Stephen Salerno
I am a post-doctoral research fellow in the Fred Hutch Data Science Lab. My research centers on statistical methods for multivariate data and machine learning for high dimensional survival analysis, as well as its applications to clinical quality measure development, public reporting efforts, and health policy surrounding kidney diseases and lung cancer. I am also passionate about applying my skill set to public service and am active in data for good initiatives at the University of Michigan and beyond.
Education:  PhD | Biostatistics | University of Michigan | 2023  MS | Biostatistics | University of Michigan | 2018  BS | Biometry & Statistics | Cornell University | 2016 
Experience:  Post-Doctoral Research Fellow | Fred Hutchinson Cancer Center | Seattle, WA

Introduction to the SRE Database
This website provides an atlas of cancer synergistic regulatory enhancer networks across different organ tissues. Designed for researchers and professionals, our platform offers an interactive, data-driven resource for exploring detailed tissue-specific data, including biosample metadata, experiment summaries, and genomic regulatory elements. Dive into organ- and tissue-specific pages, where you can explore curated data, conduct track selection, and visualize results in a genome browser to advance your research.
